item.title: Two heavy metal canisters abandoned on pavement, 25th October
item.description:
On the north side pavement opposite the NE end of Graham Mansions, in the pit of a tree planting, are two heavy metal canisters (laughing gas?) abandoned and uncollected, outside the new shopfront painted white
Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Graham Road, Hackney, London

item.title: Flytipping, 25th October
item.description:
There have been items left dumped in front of a public pathway. There is mattress strewn across the floor near the parking bays and is very unsafe and could very likely cause accidents the longer it is left there.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 27, Dewar Street, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Pothole / road defect, 25th October
item.description:
There is a dangerously sunken inspection cover outside 444 Brixton Road, SW9 8BH. The surrounding tarmac has collapsed leaving a void that can trap a bicycle wheel. On 25 October 2025 at approx 14:00 my front wheel dropped into this defect and I was thrown off, suffering cuts and bruising. This presents a serious and foreseeable hazard to cyclists and requires urgent repair.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Brixton Road, Brixton, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: House vibration from bus traffic over road manhole, 25th October
item.description:
Some years ago, works were carried where the road manhole in the picture sits. Ever since, some vibrations were felt in our house (which is just tansversal to the manhole) when a bus or equivalent passed by (not always but often, depending on its speed). In fact, a couple or so years ago as the metal cover of the whole was faulty, it made a loud noise disturbing all neighbours (which Southwark council eventually fixed the cover). However, the vibrations not only continued, they have gradually increased (they can be felt especially in the 2nd floor & loft, on the opposite side of the house). My hypothesis is that the cavity underneath the manhole has a direction towards the house, when the bus drives beyond certain speed generates a wave that transmit through the ground to the house foundations, transmiting the energy up the walls and upward till the end of the house in the 2nd floor and loft levels, manifesting itself in a vibration. We are concerned that this repeating and increasing vibration might lead to subsidience to the house (or an accident), so require immediate investigation and solution.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Princes Riverside Road, Rotherhithe, London
Report on FixMyStreet
